## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lecture, you will be able to:

::: {.incremental}

- Read and **calculate with scientific notation** (powers of ten)
- Use **SI prefixes** (kilo-, mega-, micro-, ‚Ä¶) to translate scale
- Set up **unit conversions** so units cancel (factor-label method)
- Use the **ratio method** to compare planets/stars without big-number pain
- Solve simple **rate problems** (distance = speed √ó time; amount = rate √ó time)
- Use the astronomy ‚Äúdistance ladder‚Äù units: **AU, light-year, parsec**
:::

::: {.notes}
Set the tone: "This is not a math test. It's a navigation toolkit for the universe."
:::

## Cosmic Scales in One Slide

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="58%"}
**A few anchor distances** (order-of-magnitude is enough today):

| Scale             |                     Distance |     Light travel time |
| ----------------- | ---------------------------: | --------------------: |
| Earth‚ÄìMoon        |    $3.84\times10^8\,\text{m}$ |   $\sim 1.3\,\text{s}$ |
| 1 AU (Earth‚ÄìSun)  | $1.50\times10^{11}\,\text{m}$ | $\sim 8.3\,\text{min}$ |
| 1 light-year (ly) | $9.46\times10^{15}\,\text{m}$ |                1 year |
| 1 parsec (pc)     | $3.09\times10^{16}\,\text{m}$ | $\sim 3.26\,\text{yr}$ |

: {.text-sm}
:::

::: {.column width="42%"}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}

### The key idea

Distance and time *mix* in astronomy because information travels at a finite speed.

We don‚Äôt see things **as they are**.
We see them **as they were**.
:::
:::
:::

::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
### Common trap
A **light-year** is a *distance*, not a time‚Äîeven though "year" is in the name.
It's how far light travels in one year: about 9.5 trillion km.
:::

::: {.notes}
Don't over-precision-police here; emphasize *scale literacy*. You can refine numbers later.
:::

## The Speed of Light: Nature's Speed Limit

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
Light is the fastest thing in the universe. Nothing can travel faster.

$$c = 300{,}000\,\text{km/s} = 3 \times 10^8\,\text{m/s}$$

::: {.incremental}
- Light travels **1 meter** in about 3 nanoseconds
- Light crosses **Earth's diameter** in 0.04 seconds
- Light reaches the **Moon** in 1.3 seconds
- Light reaches the **Sun** in 8.3 minutes
:::
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
{{< img lsst-cosmic-treasure-chest >}}

::: {.fragment .text-sm}
Every galaxy in this image is a **time capsule**. The light we see left millions to billions of years ago‚Äîwe're seeing them as they *were*, not as they *are*.
:::
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
1.5 min. Build the speed of light from familiar to cosmic scales.
Point to the Rubin Observatory deep field: "Each of these galaxies is at a different distance, so we're seeing them at different ages. The farthest ones appear as they were billions of years ago."
This sets up the key insight: distance = looking back in time.
:::

## What a Light-Year Really Means

A **light-year** is a *distance*, not a time‚Äîeven though "year" is in the name.

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
It's how far light travels in one year:

$$1\,\text{ly} \approx 9.5 \times 10^{15}\,\text{m}$$

That's about **9.5 trillion kilometers**.
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### Why use light-years?

"Proxima Centauri is $4 \times 10^{16}$ m away" is painful.

"4.2 light-years" is memorable.
:::
:::
:::

---

## Distance Is a Time Machine

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
Because light takes time to travel, **looking far away = looking back in time**.

| Object | Distance | You see it as it was... |
|--------|----------|-------------------------|
| Moon | 1.3 light-sec | 1.3 seconds ago |
| Sun | 8.3 light-min | 8.3 minutes ago |
| Proxima Centauri | 4.2 ly | 4.2 years ago |
| Andromeda Galaxy | 2.5 Mly | 2.5 million years ago |
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
### Mind-bending implication

The further we look, the further back in time we see.

The most distant galaxies show us the universe as it was **billions of years ago**.
:::
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
1.5 min. Let this sink in. Distance is literally a time dial.
This is why these math tools matter: we need them to decode cosmic history.
:::

## Scientific notation = brain-friendly compression

A number written as

$$a\times 10^n$$

means:

::: {.incremental}

- $a$ is the **coefficient** (usually between 1 and 10)
- $10^n$ tells you how many places the decimal moves
- $n$ is the **order of magnitude** (the scale)
:::

::: {.notes}
2 min. Walk through each bullet. Have students repeat: "a is the coefficient, n is the order of magnitude."
Muscle memory matters for notation fluency.
:::

---

## Converting: decimal ‚Üî scientific notation

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
**Big number**

$300{,}000{,}000\,\text{m/s} = 3.0\times10^8\,\text{m/s}$

**Small number**

$0.000000001\,\text{s} = 1.0\times10^{-9}\,\text{s}$
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}

### Direction rule

- $n>0$ ‚Üí move decimal **right** (bigger)
- $n<0$ ‚Üí move decimal **left** (smaller)
:::
:::
:::

---

## Operations (no calculator vibe)

::: {.incremental}

- **Multiply:** $(a\times10^m)(b\times10^n)=(ab)\times10^{m+n}$
  - *Multiply the coefficients, add the exponents*
- **Divide:** $\dfrac{a\times10^m}{b\times10^n}=\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)\times10^{m-n}$
  - *Divide the coefficients, subtract the exponents*
- **Powers:** $(a\times10^m)^k = a^k\times10^{mk}$
  - *Raise the coefficient to the power, multiply the exponent*
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### Why this works
Exponents are a shorthand for repeated multiplication. Adding exponents = multiplying powers of ten: $10^3 \times 10^2 = 10^{3+2} = 10^5$.
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
2 min. Make them say each rule out loud once. Emphasize the pattern: coefficients do normal math, exponents follow their own rules.
:::


---

## Quick Check: Scientific Notation {#stop-solve-1 background-color="#1a1a2e"}

::: {.quiz}
What is $(3 \times 10^5)(4 \times 10^3)$?

- [ ] $7 \times 10^8$
- [ ] $12 \times 10^{15}$
- [ ] $1.2 \times 10^9$
- [ ] $1.2 \times 10^8$
:::

::: {.notes}
1-2 min. Give them 30 seconds to think.
Rule: multiply coefficients, add exponents. $3 \times 4 = 12$, $5 + 3 = 8$, then normalize.

Answer: $1.2 \times 10^9$
:::

## SI Prefixes: the language of scale

| Prefix | Symbol |    Factor |
| ------ | -----: | --------: |
| tera   |      T | $10^{12}$ |
| giga   |      G |  $10^{9}$ |
| mega   |      M |  $10^{6}$ |
| kilo   |      k |  $10^{3}$ |
| milli  |      m | $10^{-3}$ |
| micro  |  $\mu$ | $10^{-6}$ |
| nano   |      n | $10^{-9}$ |

::: {.notes}
Stress: these are *power-of-ten labels*. They‚Äôre not extra information; they are the exponent.
:::

## Order-of-magnitude estimation (OoM)

When exact arithmetic is annoying, estimate on purpose.

::: {.incremental}

- Round coefficients to nearby easy numbers.
- For a **rough order-of-magnitude**:
  - coefficient $< 3$ ‚Üí round to 1
  - coefficient $> 3$ ‚Üí round to 10
:::

::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
**OoM is not "sloppy."** It's a controlled approximation for staying in the right cosmic zip code.
:::

## What's a Physical Quantity?

A **physical quantity** = a number + a unit

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### ‚úì Physical quantities
- 3 meters
- 5.9 √ó 10¬≤‚Å¥ kg
- 300,000 km/s
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
### ‚úó Not physical quantities
- "3" (three what?)
- "really far"
- "super hot"
:::
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
**The unit is not optional.** Without it, the number is meaningless.
:::

::: {.notes}
1 min. This seems obvious, but students often drop units mid-calculation.
Emphasize: a number without a unit is like a sentence without a verb.
:::

---

## What's a Physical Constant?

A **physical constant** is a number that nature gives us‚Äîit doesn't change.

::: {.incremental}
- **Speed of light:** $c = 3 \times 10^8$ m/s ‚Äî the universe's speed limit
- **Gravitational constant:** $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}$ m¬≥/(kg¬∑s¬≤) ‚Äî how strong gravity is
- **Planck's constant:** $h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34}$ J¬∑s ‚Äî the "graininess" of energy
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
### Why do constants matter?

They're **conversion factors** between different physical quantities. The speed of light $c$ converts between distance and time. That's why light-years work!
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
1.5 min. Don't dwell on the numbers‚Äîemphasize the *concept*.
Constants are nature's rules, not human choices. We discover them, we don't invent them.
:::

---

## Units vs. Dimensions (very light intro)

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
**Units** are human choices:

- meters vs kilometers vs AU

**Dimensions** are the *type* of quantity:

- length $[L]$, time $[T]$, mass $[M]$

Examples:

- speed: $[L/T]$
- area: $[L^2]$
- volume: $[L^3]$
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
{{< img units-vs-dimensions >}}

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
### Why mention dimensions?

Not to do a full "dimension analysis" unit‚Ä¶but because **unit mistakes are the #1 avoidable error** in astronomy problems.
:::
:::
:::


---

## Conversion factors = "multiply by 1"

A conversion factor is an equality written as a fraction.

Example:

$$1\,\text{m} \leftrightarrow 100\,\text{cm}$$

so you can use

$$\frac{100\,\text{cm}}{1\,\text{m}}=1 \quad \text{or} \quad \frac{1\,\text{m}}{100\,\text{cm}}=1.$$

::: {.notes}
1 min. Emphasize: conversion factor = 1. You're not changing the quantity, just the label.
This is the key insight for the factor-label method.
:::

---

## The factor-label method (foolproof)

1. Write what you‚Äôre given.

2. Multiply by conversion factors arranged so **units cancel**.

3. Check that your final units match what you wanted.

::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}

### Selection rule

Put the unit you want to **remove** in the denominator.
:::

---

## Example: minutes ‚Üí hours (structure, not memorization)

$$1000\,\text{min}\times\frac{1\,\text{hr}}{60\,\text{min}} = \frac{1000}{60}\,\text{hr}\approx 16.7\,\text{hr}$$

::: {.fragment}
**Sanity check:** hours are bigger units than minutes, so the number should get smaller. ‚úì
:::

---

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}

Astronomers measure tiny angles in **arcminutes** (1/60 of a degree) and **arcseconds** (1/60 of an arcminute). The Moon is about 30 arcmin wide; a star's disk is less than 0.05 arcsec.

**B)** Convert $0.5^\circ$ to arcseconds.

(Use: $1\,\text{mile}=1.6\,\text{km}$, $1\,\text{hr}=3600\,\text{s}$, $1^\circ=60\,\text{arcmin}$, $1\,\text{arcmin}=60\,\text{arcsec}$.)
:::

## Exponents matter in unit conversions

When a unit is squared or cubed, the conversion factor gets squared/cubed too.

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**The trap:** Students often write

$$1\,\text{m}^3 = 100\,\text{cm}^3$$ ‚ùå

**Why it's wrong:** You're converting *each* dimension.
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**The right way:**

$$1\,\text{m} = 100\,\text{cm}$$

$$1\,\text{m}^3 = (1\,\text{m})^3 = (100\,\text{cm})^3$$

$$= 100^3\,\text{cm}^3 = 10^6\,\text{cm}^3$$ ‚úì
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
**Rule:** When converting $\text{m}^n$, raise the conversion factor to the $n$th power too.
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
2 min. This is a classic student trap. Walk through slowly. Emphasize: a cubic meter is a cube with sides of 100 cm each, so the volume is $100 \times 100 \times 100$.
:::

---

## Compound Units: Building Blocks

Physics has only **three base dimensions**: length $[L]$, mass $[M]$, time $[T]$.

Everything else is built from combinations:

::: {.incremental}
- **Velocity** = distance / time ‚Üí $[L]/[T]$
- **Acceleration** = velocity / time ‚Üí $[L]/[T^2]$
- **Force** = mass √ó acceleration ‚Üí $[M][L]/[T^2]$
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### The building principle
Complex quantities are just base dimensions multiplied and divided. If you know the recipe, you can always check your work.
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
1 min. Walk through how velocity becomes acceleration becomes force.
This is dimensional analysis in miniature‚Äîcombinations of base units.
:::

---

## Reference: Common Physical Quantities {.smaller}

| Quantity | Dimension | SI Unit | Named Unit |
|----------|-----------|---------|------------|
| Length | $[L]$ | m | meter |
| Mass | $[M]$ | kg | kilogram |
| Time | $[T]$ | s | second |
| Velocity | $[L][T]^{-1}$ | m/s | ‚Äî |
| Acceleration | $[L][T]^{-2}$ | m/s¬≤ | ‚Äî |
| Force | $[M][L][T]^{-2}$ | kg¬∑m/s¬≤ | Newton (N) |
| Energy | $[M][L]^2[T]^{-2}$ | kg¬∑m¬≤/s¬≤ | Joule (J) |
| Power | $[M][L]^2[T]^{-3}$ | kg¬∑m¬≤/s¬≥ | Watt (W) |
| Pressure | $[M][L]^{-1}[T]^{-2}$ | kg/(m¬∑s¬≤) | Pascal (Pa) |

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
**Named units are shortcuts.** A Newton is just kg¬∑m/s¬≤. A Joule is just kg¬∑m¬≤/s¬≤.
If a unit looks unfamiliar, rewrite it in base units!
:::

::: {.notes}
30 sec. Don't memorize this table‚Äîuse it as a reference.
The point: all units reduce to combinations of length, mass, and time.
:::

## Absolute vs. ratio (why ratios are magic)

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
**The hard way:** Calculate Jupiter's surface gravity.

- Need: $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}$, mass, radius...
- Lots of numbers, easy to make mistakes.

**The ratio way:** Compare Jupiter to Earth.

- Jupiter is 318√ó Earth's mass, 11√ó Earth's radius
- We know Earth's gravity (9.8 m/s¬≤)
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### The pattern
If $A = k B^n$, then comparing two cases:

$$\frac{A_2}{A_1}=\left(\frac{B_2}{B_1}\right)^n$$

The constant $k$ cancels!
:::
:::
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
**What this says:** Ratios let you compare systems using only the *relationship* between quantities‚Äîno need to look up constants.
:::

---

## Scaling patterns you‚Äôll use all semester

| Scaling         | Meaning                  | Where it shows up                 |
| --------------- | ------------------------ | --------------------------------- |
| $\propto R^2$   | area grows fast          | telescope area, surface area      |
| $\propto R^3$   | volume grows *very* fast | planet volumes, ‚Äúhow many Earths‚Äù |
| $\propto 1/r^2$ | inverse-square           | brightness, gravity               |

---

## Worked Example: Telescope Collecting Area {.smaller}

**Problem:** The Keck telescope has a 10-meter diameter mirror. The Hubble Space Telescope has a 2.4-meter diameter mirror. How much more light can Keck collect?

::: {.fragment}
**Setup:** Light-collecting area scales as $A \propto D^2$ (area of a circle)
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Ratio method:**
$$\frac{A_\text{Keck}}{A_\text{Hubble}} = \left(\frac{D_\text{Keck}}{D_\text{Hubble}}\right)^2 = \left(\frac{10}{2.4}\right)^2 \approx (4.2)^2 \approx 17$$
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Answer:** Keck collects about **17√ó more light** than Hubble‚Äîno need to calculate actual areas!
:::

::: {.notes}
2 min. Walk through step by step. Emphasize: we never needed to know $\pi$ or calculate actual square meters.
The ratio $D_2/D_1$ does all the work. Students often want to compute $\pi r^2$ for both‚Äîshow them this shortcut.
:::

---

## Quick Check: Volume Ratio {#stop-solve-3 background-color="#1a1a2e"}

The Sun's radius is about 109√ó Earth's radius. How many Earths fit inside the Sun?

::: {.quiz}
Using $V \propto R^3$, what is $V_\odot / V_\oplus$?

- [ ] About 109
- [ ] About 12,000
- [ ] About 1.3 million
- [ ] About 109 million
:::

::: {.notes}
1-2 min. $109^3 \approx 1.3 \times 10^6$.
Key insight: volume grows as the *cube* of radius‚Äîmuch faster than area or length.

Answer: About 1.3 million
:::

## Applying the Pattern: Comparing Stars

**What we measure:** Brightness ratio of two stars (same apparent brightness)

**What physics says:** Inverse-square law means equal brightness at different distances implies different luminosities

**What we conclude:** A star 10√ó further away but equally bright must be **100√ó more luminous**

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### The ratio shortcut
$\frac{L_2}{L_1} = \left(\frac{d_2}{d_1}\right)^2 = 10^2 = 100$
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
1 min. Second use of Observable ‚Üí Model ‚Üí Inference.
Ratios + inverse-square = powerful tool for stellar comparison.
:::

## Inverse-square intuition (brightness)

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
If you move twice as far from a light source:

$$\text{brightness}\propto \frac{1}{d^2}$$

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
### Watch the flip!
Because brightness is *inversely* proportional to $d^2$, the ratio flips:

$$\frac{B_2}{B_1}=\left(\frac{d_1}{d_2}\right)^2$$

Farther distance on bottom ‚Üí smaller brightness.
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Example:** $d_2 = 2d_1$ (twice as far)

$$\frac{B_2}{B_1}=\left(\frac{d_1}{2d_1}\right)^2=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2=\frac{1}{4}$$
:::
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
{{< img inverse-square-law >}}
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
Astronomers call this brightness measurement **flux** ‚Äî the energy arriving per second per unit area (W/m¬≤). This is why distance is *hard* in astronomy: small distance errors become big flux errors.
:::

::: {.notes}
2 min. Draw attention to the diagram. Light spreads over area = 4œÄd¬≤.
Double the distance ‚Üí 4√ó the area ‚Üí 1/4 the brightness per unit area.
:::

---

## Worked Example: Mars Sunlight {.smaller}

**Problem:** Mars orbits at 1.5 AU from the Sun. Earth orbits at 1 AU. How does the intensity of sunlight on Mars compare to Earth?

::: {.fragment}
**Setup:** Sunlight intensity follows the inverse-square law: $I \propto 1/d^2$
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Ratio method:**
$$\frac{I_\text{Mars}}{I_\text{Earth}} = \left(\frac{d_\text{Earth}}{d_\text{Mars}}\right)^2 = \left(\frac{1}{1.5}\right)^2 = \left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^2 = \frac{4}{9} \approx 0.44$$
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Answer:** Mars receives only **44% as much sunlight** as Earth‚Äîless than half!

This is why Mars is so cold, and why solar panels on Mars rovers need to be larger.
:::

::: {.notes}
2 min. Walk through carefully. Note the d terms flip because brightness is *inversely* proportional to d¬≤.
Students often get confused about which distance goes on top‚Äîremind them: farther away = less light.
Real-world consequence: Mars surface temperature averages ‚àí60¬∞C.
:::

---

## Applying the Pattern: Distance from Brightness

**What we measure:** Brightness (flux $F$) ‚Äî how much light arrives at our detector (W/m¬≤)

**What physics says:** Inverse-square law relates flux, luminosity, and distance:

$$F = \frac{L}{4\pi d^2}$$

where $L$ = luminosity (total power output, in Watts) and $d$ = distance

**What we conclude:** If we know a star's true luminosity $L$ and measure its flux $F$, we can solve for distance $d$

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### The inference chain
Observable ($F$) ‚Üí Model (inverse-square) ‚Üí Physical property ($d$)
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
1 min. This is the first explicit use of the Observable ‚Üí Model ‚Üí Inference pattern.
Refer back to Lecture 1. We'll use this pattern all semester.
:::

::: {.r-fit-text}
Tool 4: Rate Problems
:::

*Change per time is basically the universe's favorite sentence structure*

::: {.notes}
0.5 min. Section transition. Let the tagline land.
:::

## The rate template

Most rate problems are one equation with three rearrangements:

$$\text{amount} = \text{rate}\times\text{time}$$

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.incremental}
- **Find rate:** $\text{rate}=\dfrac{\text{amount}}{\text{time}}$
  - *"How fast?"*
- **Find time:** $\text{time}=\dfrac{\text{amount}}{\text{rate}}$
  - *"How long?"*
- **Find amount:** $\text{amount}=\text{rate}\times\text{time}$
  - *"How much/far?"*
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### Astronomy examples
- **Distance** = speed √ó time
- **Energy** = power √ó time
- **Mass loss** = rate √ó time
:::
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
**What this says:** If you know any two of these, you can find the third. This single pattern solves most "how far/fast/long" questions.
:::

---

## Worked Example: Building a Light-Year {.smaller}

**Problem:** How far does light travel in one year? (In meters)

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Step 1: Identify the rate equation**

$$\text{distance} = \text{speed} \times \text{time}$$

**Step 2: Gather your values**

- Speed of light: $c = 3 \times 10^8\,\text{m/s}$
- Time: $1\,\text{year}$

But wait‚Äîthe units don't match! We need time in **seconds**.
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Step 3: Convert 1 year ‚Üí seconds**

$$1\,\text{yr} \times \frac{365\,\text{days}}{1\,\text{yr}} \times \frac{24\,\text{hr}}{1\,\text{day}} \times \frac{3600\,\text{s}}{1\,\text{hr}}$$

$$= 365 \times 24 \times 3600\,\text{s}$$

$$\approx 3.15 \times 10^7\,\text{s}$$
:::
:::

---

## Worked Example: Building a Light-Year (continued) {.smaller}

**Step 4: Multiply using scientific notation**

$$1\,\text{ly} = c \times t = (3 \times 10^8\,\text{m/s}) \times (3.15 \times 10^7\,\text{s})$$

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### Scientific notation multiplication rule
**Multiply coefficients, add exponents:** $(a \times 10^m) \times (b \times 10^n) = (a \times b) \times 10^{m+n}$
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
$$= (3 \times 3.15) \times 10^{8+7}\,\text{m}$$
$$= 9.45 \times 10^{15}\,\text{m}$$
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Answer:** $1\,\text{ly} \approx 9.5 \times 10^{15}\,\text{m}$ (about 9.5 trillion kilometers)
:::

::: {.notes}
3 min total for both slides. Walk through each step deliberately.
Emphasize: (1) unit conversion chain, (2) scientific notation multiplication rule, (3) units cancel (s/s = 1).
This is a template for ALL rate problems: distance = speed √ó time.
:::

---

## Applying the Pattern: Lookback Time

**What we measure:** Distance to a galaxy (in light-years)

**What physics says:** Light travels at $c = 3 \times 10^8$ m/s (finite speed)

**What we conclude:** A galaxy 2.5 million light-years away ‚Üí we see it as it was **2.5 million years ago**

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
Distance is a time machine. The further we look, the further back in time we see.
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
1 min. Third use of Observable ‚Üí Model ‚Üí Inference.
Connect to the "distance = time dial" concept from Lecture 1.
:::

## Putting it together: a problem-solving checklist

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}

### The decoding ritual

For any quantitative astronomy question:
:::

::: {.incremental}

1. **What am I finding?** (write target with units)
2. **What am I given?** (write givens with units)
3. **Pick the tool:** conversion, ratio, or rate
4. **Do the unit cancellation** (this is your error detector)
5. **Sanity check:** bigger unit ‚Üí smaller number? right power of ten?
:::

## What to Take Away

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
### Recognition, not retention

You don't need to memorize formulas. You need to **recognize patterns**:

- Powers of ten compress cosmic scales
- Ratios reveal relationships without constants
- Units keep your equations honest
- Rates connect distance, time, and speed
:::

::: {.fragment}
When you see a big number or a scaling question, you'll know which tool to reach for.
:::

::: {.notes}

- $2\,\text{AU}$: $2\times 8.3\,\text{min}\approx 16.6\,\text{min}$

## Solution 1 {#solution-1}

**Step 1: Multiply the coefficients**
$$3 \times 4 = 12$$

**Step 2: Add the exponents**
$$10^5 \times 10^3 = 10^{5+3} = 10^8$$

**Step 3: Combine**
$$12 \times 10^8$$

**Step 4: Normalize** (coefficient should be between 1 and 10)
$$12 \times 10^8 = 1.2 \times 10^9$$

[‚Üê Back](#stop-solve-1)

::: {.notes}
1 min. Walk through each step deliberately. The normalization step catches students‚Äîremind them that $12 = 1.2 \times 10^1$, so we add 1 to the exponent.
:::

## Solution 2 {#solution-2}

### A) $60\,\text{mph} \to \text{m/s}$

$$60 \frac{\text{mile}}{\text{hr}}\times\frac{1.6\,\text{km}}{1\,\text{mile}}\times\frac{1000\,\text{m}}{1\,\text{km}}\times\frac{1\,\text{hr}}{3600\,\text{s}}\approx 26.7\,\text{m/s}$$

### B) $0.5^\circ \to \text{arcsec}$

$$0.5^\circ\times\frac{60\,\text{arcmin}}{1^\circ}\times\frac{60\,\text{arcsec}}{1\,\text{arcmin}}=1800\,\text{arcsec}$$

[‚Üê Back](#stop-solve-2)

::: {.notes}
45 sec. Emphasize unit cancellation ‚Äî watch the units disappear step by step.
:::

## Solution 3 {#solution-3}

$$109^3 \approx (1.09\times10^2)^3 = 1.09^3\times10^6\approx 1.3\times10^6.$$

So the Sun's volume is about **1.3 million Earth volumes**.

[‚Üê Back](#stop-solve-3)

::: {.notes}
30 sec. The cube makes a huge difference ‚Äî radius ratio of 109 becomes volume ratio of 1.3 million.
:::

## Solution 4 {#solution-4}

$$29.8\,\text{km/s} = 2.98\times10^4\,\text{m/s}$$

One minute is $60\,\text{s}$, so

$$\text{distance}=vt=(2.98\times10^4\,\text{m/s})(60\,\text{s})\approx 1.79\times10^6\,\text{m}.$$

That's about **1800 km** in one minute.

[‚Üê Back](#stop-solve-4)

::: {.notes}
30 sec. Rate √ó time = distance. Earth covers almost 2000 km every minute ‚Äî cosmic speeds are fast!
:::
